key_title: Key to the species of Mentha

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Salvia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria Vol. 4 Dicotyledons Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Conn, B.J. (1999). Salvia. In: Walsh, N.G, Entwisle, T.J., Flora of Victoria Vol. 4 Dicotyledons Cornaceae to Asteraceae, pp. 428-430. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flower-clusters in distal leaf-axils, with distinctly visible internodes between the fertile nodes; calyx 13-veined (except M. pulegium 10-veined)

Flower-clusters terminal, forming a spike-like inflorescence, clusters subtended by narrow bracts, not subtended by leaves, with internodes frequently not visible between the fertile nodes; calyx 10-veined
Margins of calyx-lobes villous to pilose on inner surface; flowers 3–8 per axil
Margins of calyx-lobes glabrous or with short, usually erect hairs on inner surface, not conspicuously more densely hairy than outer surface of calyx tube; flowers few-many per axil

Branches and calyx hairy; flowers in 3–8-flowered clusters per leaf-axil; leaves ovate, often angular-ovate, rarely narrowly ovate or elliptic, 6–20 mm long, 4–12 mm wide; margin entire or sometimes with distant shallow serrations

Branches almost glabrous; calyx almost or quite glabrous on outer surface; flowers in 3-flowered clusters per leaf-axil; leaves narrowly elliptic to linear-elliptic, 5–35 mm long, 2–7 mm wide; margin entire
Pedicels usually subequal to or longer than calyces; flowers 2–8 (–12) per axil; leaves obtuse to subacute; pedicels usually subequal to or longer than calyces
Pedicels much shorter than calyces; flowers mostly crowded in dense clusters, 8-many flowers per axil, or if ever fewer than 6 flowers per axil, then leaves acute
Leaves narrowly ovate, 12–60 mm long, 8–20 mm wide, margin with 2–7 serrations, apex acute; calyx 13-veined; corolla white or pink
Leaves obovate, elliptic to almost orbicular, 6–30 mm long, 4–20 mm wide, margin entire or with small blunt serrations, apex obtuse or rounded; calyx 10-veined; corolla usually pale-mauve to lilac
Basal leaves petiolate; plants not producing fruits; calyx-lobes c. half as long as calyx-tube
Basal leaves sessile; plants producing fruits; calyx-lobes half as long to c. equal to calyx-tube
Leaves very obtuse to rounded at apex, indumentum of lower surface including some branched hairs
Leaves acute at apex, or if ever obtuse, hairs of lower surface all simple
Leaves villous beneath, hirsute above; inflorescence usually interrupted
Leaves (at least of mature growth) glabrous to sparsely hairy; inflorescence usually uninterrupted
